Hnel handed him the resolves.--- Who then does not see the combination ?--- This Business was planned, matnred, and exe- 'cuted, with no little cunning and without even a suspicion en the part ot the person or per. sons they would rttempt to criminate that such measure would be discussed, till the resolves weae published. Is this the course that honor, manhood, or equity ineulcates? Nc: It Is violation of all law. and a direct infr'ngepent of the rules of the Medical So- ciety. But iR the execution Ofsnch measures, law, and honor. and integrity are not taken into the account; but meanness and detesta-. oie da rkness constitute the engines eff power.

 A number Of the regular members who were absent from the meeting, have express ed regret aud indignation !" at the second resolve oftheir brethren; since after strict in- yestigati0n they can fiDd no schere the least .s- teeavt' to calusnniate Dr. Sheldon. Its author or authors were deeply tinctured with the same spirit they would wish to condemn; and we are entirely willing that they should derive all the consolation and benefit resulting from it ;- putin their calm reAecting moments, when reason rules. and passion shrinks away, we ensy not their happinsssss

DANCING SCHOOL.

 MIR. FULLER.

Mr. SMITH--

 As have been siuce its cOmmenceme a constant reader of your paper, have remark cd that it has embraced variety of useful and interesting subjects.-The political discussions have read patiently. Knowing that of course they would subside when the struggle was over, the anticipation ofwhich had called thesn before the public. ..

 But there is one subject which in my opin- :on is worthy of consideration, which has been almost wholly neglected; and have wait cd for yeaTs.hoping that some abler pen would present it to the public, and particularly to the inhabitants of Litchkeld County-l mean Church Music. might probably not coniine my remarks to this County when say. that very many of the supporters of our ecclesiasti- cal societies, manifest towards this subject a most astonishing, most criminal indifference. This think arises from the fact that music is 70 very little understood by the community at large: they do not consider. or they do not know, that it is science which most per. sons can cultivate equally with Arithmetic, English Grammar, or even the art of Read ing. True, they. should begin while y0lngl and it IS far the bene6fOf such that make these remarks. There are some who seem tc
FOR THE COUNTY POST.

bO- convinced that it is possible for them to be made to undcrstRnd the subject, but are de- tered frUm undertaking it for want of suGFi cient time. Now Sir. were it not for extend ing this communication to animprOper length, 1 would undertake to show from reasons and facts, that this is mistake. would show many of these same individuals that they have spent more time at Singing School than would suffice to render them capable of per forming any piece of common church music at sight, or at most by a very few moments preparatiOn.-But from the negligence sf the pupil, or the unfaithfulness or ignoranceOf the teacher. or frequently all of these reasons uni ted, the time tbus spent is almost wasted, and the money which supported the school frequently misapplied. Schools are frequent y commenced with the expectation of doing bat little, andiB. that respect, if in no other, our expectations are fully rt.aiized. For the teacher, anxious to please his employers. who

 

 ifhAirexertisnas isaeissn crowd his pupils for ward before they have become equsinted with the first prineipiesofthe science.le4 consequently they anea unable ts procsrJ ssas astep farther than they are led 'by their teacISer,s and can give no better sesson for tE.eir pesft6ruaaAices than that their teacher. CT some other person, has perfornsdin the same manner. While practising in school, a few pieces of church music are sung over, and over, and over till no one can be supposed to forgot them, and then they are said to be learned and the school closes for the season. Alter this, when the patrons of the school assemble on the sab bath for worship, and hoping for assistance in their devotions from the choir. in return for their libcra!ity in supporting it. how grievously are they disappointed. The younger singers occasionally ,and perhaps some of their fathers occasionally too, take their seats in the choir for an afternoon, and the singing is conducted merely as interludes between the scenes to enable the audience to relax their attention, and to give the preacher time to take breath 1; for both the preacher and: the audience too frequently seem to regard the singing as a part in which they have no concern; and also they seem not to be aware that while preach- ing is DO where ia Scripture spoken of as al part of morshsp. singing is mentioned perhaps even more frequently than prayer.-But the singers having been accustomed to drilling over their tunes in school until they have lost their intrrest, seon become disgusted and abandon their seats, resolved t" lMy no attention to an art 50 uninteresting and contemptible.- And no wonder they think so for from the example oftheir fathers. they have DO. reason so tiiink it duty; and from their own expe- rience they do not expect any pleasure from the performance. But the evil does not stop here; the congregation finding that the sing school closes, begin to recollect that 1t always wasso; and hence they conclude 1t always will be so: and further, that it will do no good to take any measures to remedy an evil which by this time they conceive is sirremediable.- But notwithstanding, there arc doubtless rem edies, and those remedies too within onr reach. for there are instances where the subject has been treated in some measure with the isDpor- tance 1t deserves, and the experiment bas sat isfied most of those concerned. that the ad- tages resulting from well regulated Singing Schools. are such as shsuld recommend them selves to the liberal patronage of every well wishcr to community, and every friend of Religion and Morality. STOCCATO.

 State Legislature.

 YYnVYcE nE pEpP CCrNT TsTVEC

scarcely fourth part Ofihem; how then can ie be said that those republicans who are sO unfortunate as to be represented by federal ists, alone complain of legislative caucusses. l Several other speeches were made, in all of which the utmost respect was manifested to- wards his Majesty King Caucus it was how ever decided to refer the business to com- mittee of three from a county, to report at an adjourned meeting to be holden this evening, CFhnrsday May 17th) upon the best mode of nominating, Oti0s electing, Senators for the year 1893. The three from this county were Messrs. Burrall, from Canaan Bierce. from Cornwall, and Phelps, from C0lebrOOk. We may here remark that Judge Weich has de- clined reelection to the office of Senator.- Why he chose to decline to Legislative Can- GUS, rather than to the freemen of Coupecti- cut, Is best known to himself

 We have heretofore opposed Legislative Caucusses ;--we have said that representa- 'siEes thus assembling, were assuming an un- warrantable degree of power. by yirtuaIsys making the higher branches of the legislature subservient to their interests ;--sse have said; that eur elections were free only ia the nanne;i % long as our representatives claimed the right of dictating who shall, and who shall mot hh important state offices ;-we have said that legislative cauclsses were destructive .to the purity of legislative acts, hy,making every important measure more or less subservient to the interests of the caucus, and that the friends of caucusses, immediately on entering upon the duties of the station to which they have been appointed, bend the whole powers of their mind to this one question, who shall rule over us next year? instead of honestly doing the duties of their appointment, and leaving the people to consider that question eleven months from this time. We have seen no reason to change our mind upon this snb- lect. We asked a republican member of the House whether any of the above mentioned evils were felt at the present session. His aD- swer was, Yes, all of them, and many more. There are several petitions before the House. for new banks, new turnpikes, new incorpo- cations of different kinds, and votes are bought and sold for ail these bills. simply by caucus influence. A member who has an interest in new bank charter, asks the support of

 member from different section of the state {; immediately a whispering commences, and pledges are given-if you will vote for sucha man in the caucus, will vote fur your bill.'' These things" said the member, ..' are wit messed every day and know of no greater curse to a legislature than originates from caucus influence; it embitters members to- wards each other those aia0 are upy,y slo legislative caucusses are lOoled upon with jealousy; their every act is supposed to have aparty political hearing. and is therefore most vigorously contested; and indeed those re- publican members of the House who desire [" refev the right of nominating as well as e'ccting. state and county officers, entirely te the people, are hated by the caucus men far worse than the frderalists sre." Are these 'hings so Jf our representatives possess the stern integrity of a Franklin, they are not but if they are men, possessed ofthe ferlings, passions and jeaIouses, of great majority of mankind. they are not only true. but much more than has heen said is true in relation to fhe haIefui influence of legislative caucusses. We have opposed these meetings, not because Ofthc men who support them,-ior many of them we have called .f-iends,-but because we have candidly viewed them as unwarran- table assumptions of power--a source ofcer- vnpfion and intrigue, which every state tn New England, with the exception of Con- necticnt, has freed themselves from ;--which even New York has abandoned. as one of the greatest inlets to corrupt legislation, and irn- pure and imbecile government.

 A bill fora public act t0 repeal an>act pass ed the last sessien for taxing sheep, Was read the third time. A discuss,on of some length ensued, in which Mrssrs. Warren, D. Bacon, Ingersoll,D. S. Boatdmaihf and Griswold, ad- vocated and Messrs. Shepard, Harley, and Ellswo orth, opposed the bill. 1t was urged tn support of the bill, that it was in conformity with what had always been considered the true policy of the State, as it opperated to ell4 couraged manufactures ; that the price soe wool was low, and although thestax was tri- fling, afforded hut little revenae, 1t bad a tens dency to discourage farmers from raising sheep; that distinction as regards the kind OfprOpelty subjected to taxation, were prO- per, when the public good required it, and had always existed. Against ttslbilf it was urged that the public good and the interest of manu- factures did not require it as the market was we'll supplied with wool ]; that it opperated to the beneRt of the wealthy and the injury of the poor, that it was negotiable and op- posed to the constitution as afforded exciu- sise privileges. On taking the vote the bill was negatived. As- ,ea.'

 Alter refiecting few moments he smiled si,.- nifcantly, hut refused to answer. Nov t5s fact is, there are between sixty and eipbfv regular Physicians in this County. of whom . peFy ttMsfed number, we are certain, atteDd- ed the meeting. The, sentiment then thev would wish to advance. in saying thaf fIss Medical Society passed thtse resolves. scal- culated widely to mislead.

 Dr. s. R. ChiIds has been questioned un on :his subject by ore ar more regular Physi. clans, and members of the Society, but decli- ned giving any direct answers to the nunaer. o.is questions pr0posed by them, except that Dr,s m. Hnel handed him the resolves.--- Who then does not see the combination ?--- This Business was planned, matnred, and exe- 'cuted, with no little cunning and without even a suspicion en the part ot the person or per. sons they would rttempt to criminate that such measure would be discussed, till the resolves weae published. Is this the course that honor, manhood, or equity ineulcates? Nc: It Is violation of all law. and a direct infr'ngepent of the rules of the Medical So- ciety. But iR the execution Ofsnch measures, law, and honor. and integrity are not taken into the account; but meanness and detesta-. oie da rkness constitute the engines eff power.

 A number Of the regular members who were absent from the meeting, have express ed regret aud indignation !" at the second resolve oftheir brethren; since after strict in- yestigati0n they can fiDd no schere the least .s- teeavt' to calusnniate Dr. Sheldon. This scur- rilons resolve then. is nothing less than HbeL upon the person or persons they would "at- tempt" to censure, ,and by no means creditable to the distinguished individual they so justly cul0gi2e iD the first. Its author or authors were deeply tinctured with the same spirit they would wish to condemn; and we are entirely willing that they should derive all the consolation and benefit resulting from it ;- putin their calm reAecting moments, when reason rules. and passion shrinks away, we ensy not their happinsssss

 A resolution from the Senate appointing the H0p. Mir. Crawford with such other gentle- men as the House may join. on committee on all applications for lotteries passed. and the committee on the part of the House was ordered to consist of one from each County.

 A resolution from the Senate appointing the Hon. MT. Aslop. with such gentlemen as the House may join, committee to- take into consideration the laws relating to Common Schools, and enquire what alterations, if any, are necessary to be made in the same, was read. It was objected to by Mir. Shepard on the ground that the .House ought to act inde- pendently; that is dignity was impaired by reference of such subjects to joint commit- tees :; and that therefore select committee was preferable. He wasreplied to by Messrs. Grisw olll, Gurley. T. S. Williams and War ren, all of whom advocated the appointment of joint committee. The resolution f0r . iOint committee was adopted, and the follow ing gentlemen app0intad by fhe Speaker an the part of the House. ;ts

 The petition of the Tariff Manufactnrine Company Tor relief against certain ObstTuc tiOns in EnEnington FiSer, was referred to select committee of one from county. Seve' raj other petitions were received and disposed l of by reference sto' committees.

 he report Of the Agents of the Eagle Bank vas read and laid on thetable; wai,t of fOOtiI e0nlpels US to omit it. The repOtt df The committee OH the State Hnuss in Hartford was resumed. After a short explanation from Mr. Hill, one of the committee, the report was accepted, and the accompanying resolutions, author ising an appropriation of $500 for repairs. passed,

 Bills were passed appointing David Bolls, Esq. Chief Judge. and Vine Rob- ilasslsa aad John Danlap. Esqrs. Associate Judges of the County Court of Windham County. Bills we're passed appoiasing the Hon. Sanaea W. Dana, Chief Judge, and Wm. Carter and Franklin c. Comstock, Esqrs. Associate Judges of the County Court for the County of Middlesex.

 Friday May II.

full articles.headline: FOR THE COUNTY POST.
full articles.article:
Mr. SMITH--

 As have been siuce its cOmmenceme a constant reader of your paper, have remark cd that it has embraced variety of useful and interesting subjects.-The political discussions have read patiently. Knowing that of course they would subside when the struggle was over, the anticipation ofwhich had called thesn before the public. ..

 But there is one subject which in my opin- :on is worthy of consideration, which has been almost wholly neglected; and have wait cd for yeaTs.hoping that some abler pen would present it to the public, and particularly to the inhabitants of Litchkeld County-l mean Church Music. might probably not coniine my remarks to this County when say. that very many of the supporters of our ecclesiasti- cal societies, manifest towards this subject a most astonishing, most criminal indifference. This think arises from the fact that music is 70 very little understood by the community at large: they do not consider. or they do not know, that it is science which most per. sons can cultivate equally with Arithmetic, English Grammar, or even the art of Read ing. True, they. should begin while y0lngl and it IS far the bene6fOf such that make these remarks. There are some who seem tc

bO- convinced that it is possible for them to be made to undcrstRnd the subject, but are de- tered frUm undertaking it for want of suGFi cient time. Now Sir. were it not for extend ing this communication to animprOper length, 1 would undertake to show from reasons and facts, that this is mistake. would show many of these same individuals that they have spent more time at Singing School than would suffice to render them capable of per forming any piece of common church music at sight, or at most by a very few moments preparatiOn.-But from the negligence sf the pupil, or the unfaithfulness or ignoranceOf the teacher. or frequently all of these reasons uni ted, the time tbus spent is almost wasted, and the money which supported the school frequently misapplied. Schools are frequent y commenced with the expectation of doing bat little, andiB. that respect, if in no other, our expectations are fully rt.aiized. For the teacher, anxious to please his employers. who

 

 ifhAirexertisnas isaeissn crowd his pupils for ward before they have become equsinted with the first prineipiesofthe science.le4 consequently they anea unable ts procsrJ ssas astep farther than they are led 'by their teacISer,s and can give no better sesson for tE.eir pesft6ruaaAices than that their teacher. CT some other person, has perfornsdin the same manner. While practising in school, a few pieces of church music are sung over, and over, and over till no one can be supposed to forgot them, and then they are said to be learned and the school closes for the season. Alter this, when the patrons of the school assemble on the sab bath for worship, and hoping for assistance in their devotions from the choir. in return for their libcra!ity in supporting it. how grievously are they disappointed. The younger singers occasionally ,and perhaps some of their fathers occasionally too, take their seats in the choir for an afternoon, and the singing is conducted merely as interludes between the scenes to enable the audience to relax their attention, and to give the preacher time to take breath 1; for both the preacher and: the audience too frequently seem to regard the singing as a part in which they have no concern; and also they seem not to be aware that while preach- ing is DO where ia Scripture spoken of as al part of morshsp. singing is mentioned perhaps even more frequently than prayer.-But the singers having been accustomed to drilling over their tunes in school until they have lost their intrrest, seon become disgusted and abandon their seats, resolved t" lMy no attention to an art 50 uninteresting and contemptible.- And no wonder they think so for from the example oftheir fathers. they have DO. reason so tiiink it duty; and from their own expe- rience they do not expect any pleasure from the performance. But the evil does not stop here; the congregation finding that the sing school closes, begin to recollect that 1t always wasso; and hence they conclude 1t always will be so: and further, that it will do no good to take any measures to remedy an evil which by this time they conceive is sirremediable.- But notwithstanding, there arc doubtless rem edies, and those remedies too within onr reach. for there are instances where the subject has been treated in some measure with the isDpor- tance 1t deserves, and the experiment bas sat isfied most of those concerned. that the ad- tages resulting from well regulated Singing Schools. are such as shsuld recommend them selves to the liberal patronage of every well wishcr to community, and every friend of Religion and Morality. STOCCATO.

 State Legislature.

 YYnVYcE nE pEpP CCrNT TsTVEC

scarcely fourth part Ofihem; how then can ie be said that those republicans who are sO unfortunate as to be represented by federal ists, alone complain of legislative caucusses. l Several other speeches were made, in all of which the utmost respect was manifested to- wards his Majesty King Caucus it was how ever decided to refer the business to com- mittee of three from a county, to report at an adjourned meeting to be holden this evening, CFhnrsday May 17th) upon the best mode of nominating, Oti0s electing, Senators for the year 1893. The three from this county were Messrs. Burrall, from Canaan Bierce. from Cornwall, and Phelps, from C0lebrOOk. We may here remark that Judge Weich has de- clined reelection to the office of Senator.- Why he chose to decline to Legislative Can- GUS, rather than to the freemen of Coupecti- cut, Is best known to himself

 We have heretofore opposed Legislative Caucusses ;--we have said that representa- 'siEes thus assembling, were assuming an un- warrantable degree of power. by yirtuaIsys making the higher branches of the legislature subservient to their interests ;--sse have said; that eur elections were free only ia the nanne;i % long as our representatives claimed the right of dictating who shall, and who shall mot hh important state offices ;-we have said that legislative cauclsses were destructive .to the purity of legislative acts, hy,making every important measure more or less subservient to the interests of the caucus, and that the friends of caucusses, immediately on entering upon the duties of the station to which they have been appointed, bend the whole powers of their mind to this one question, who shall rule over us next year? instead of honestly doing the duties of their appointment, and leaving the people to consider that question eleven months from this time. We have seen no reason to change our mind upon this snb- lect. We asked a republican member of the House whether any of the above mentioned evils were felt at the present session. His aD- swer was, Yes, all of them, and many more. There are several petitions before the House. for new banks, new turnpikes, new incorpo- cations of different kinds, and votes are bought and sold for ail these bills. simply by caucus influence. A member who has an interest in new bank charter, asks the support of

 member from different section of the state {; immediately a whispering commences, and pledges are given-if you will vote for sucha man in the caucus, will vote fur your bill.'' These things" said the member, ..' are wit messed every day and know of no greater curse to a legislature than originates from caucus influence; it embitters members to- wards each other those aia0 are upy,y slo legislative caucusses are lOoled upon with jealousy; their every act is supposed to have aparty political hearing. and is therefore most vigorously contested; and indeed those re- publican members of the House who desire [" refev the right of nominating as well as e'ccting. state and county officers, entirely te the people, are hated by the caucus men far worse than the frderalists sre." Are these 'hings so Jf our representatives possess the stern integrity of a Franklin, they are not but if they are men, possessed ofthe ferlings, passions and jeaIouses, of great majority of mankind. they are not only true. but much more than has heen said is true in relation to fhe haIefui influence of legislative caucusses. We have opposed these meetings, not because Ofthc men who support them,-ior many of them we have called .f-iends,-but because we have candidly viewed them as unwarran- table assumptions of power--a source ofcer- vnpfion and intrigue, which every state tn New England, with the exception of Con- necticnt, has freed themselves from ;--which even New York has abandoned. as one of the greatest inlets to corrupt legislation, and irn- pure and imbecile government.

 FOR THE COUNTY POST.

 As have been siuce its commencement, a constant reader of your paper, have remark cd that it has embraced a variety of useful and n

ting tO the assessment of taxes was read the second time. The object of the bin is the repeal of law passed the last session Cor tax ing sheep. Mir. D. s. B0ardman briefly stated that he was induced to lay i1 the bill on aE- count Oftle great depression. which hadteken place in the value of sheep and wool si,ssI passage of the iaw.-PosfpOned to hSlliri reading. .Sl

 A bill for public act relative to the sStllsA ment of estates testate, intesfate and ins0lyanGs was introduced by MT. Benedict aud FcGd the first time.

 | A bill for a public act concerning duties and court fees was taken up oa its second read ing. and its object explained by Mr. Garleys-- The first section of the hill aholishes the du- ties on all writs. petitions, and appeals; tine second section provides for an increaAs of court fees. The bill was amended hy striking out the second section. and postponed tO < third reading. Afternoon. @ : A bill for public act relating to fences and cOanm0n ielsls, received its first and. sst0nd reading. nt A resolution was intf0ancsd. directing the COmptT0iler tn.procure 20 copies of the Stat ute laws uf the state for the use of the Honse. A shart dehafe eRstIed ,and the resolution atter beinR agneasIed so asstO reduce the number to 12, passed.

 The petition oftie Geoesal Hospital socie- Ety of Connecticut, for RI in establishing lhOspitai in the city of sNes Haven, was ore. sented by Mr. Hslbb&fd and referred to a com mittee of one froma c0nnty. The House hav- ing no business on the table, adjourned. " .a. . a Tuesday, May 8.

 A bill fora public act t0 repeal an>act pass ed the last sessien for taxing sheep, Was read the third time. A discuss,on of some length ensued, in which Mrssrs. Warren, D. Bacon, Ingersoll,D. S. Boatdmaihf and Griswold, ad- vocated and Messrs. Shepard, Harley, and Ellswo orth, opposed the bill. 1t was urged tn support of the bill, that it was in conformity with what had always been considered the true policy of the State, as it opperated to ell4 couraged manufactures ; that the price soe wool was low, and although thestax was tri- fling, afforded hut little revenae, 1t bad a tens dency to discourage farmers from raising sheep; that distinction as regards the kind OfprOpelty subjected to taxation, were prO- per, when the public good required it, and had always existed. Against ttslbilf it was urged that the public good and the interest of manu- factures did not require it as the market was we'll supplied with wool ]; that it opperated to the beneRt of the wealthy and the injury of the poor, that it was negotiable and op- posed to the constitution as afforded exciu- sise privileges. On taking the vote the bill was negatived. As- ,ea.'

 The bill for a public act c0sscerning duties and court fees was read the third time, and, after being amended so as to repeal so much of the existing statute as Is contrary to the provision of the bill, passed.

 Several petitions for a TeversiOn of the laws relating to common schools. were presented and referred to the committee on this subject.

 Afternoon.

 A bill fora public act to repeal an act con corning schools, received its first and second readings. %a s 1.a F --','2@r 2-r-r~ Wednesday. DSay S.se r A message gr0m the 0userupf, trans uniting certain resolutions of fhe State of Maine, relating to the appropriation of the the revenue ofthe U. States for the purpose of internal improvement, was read and re- ferred to joint cemmiftee consieting oi' one from a county on the part of the House. N, as' .gs4 .-,s :,

 A message from the Governor trans- hitting certain resolutions of the State of Georgia and Ohio relating the elections of President and Vice President of the Uni- ted States, was referred to the same com mittee. 59. r.-.

 A large nnmber of petitions were pre- scn,ed, among which were the petitions of the Trustees of Washington College for pecuniasy aid. Of the Hartford Fire In- ssasance Company for power to effec, ma- rine insurance. Of Jeremiah Sturges and others for a Bank at Sangatuck, &c.--Of John Baldwin and others for smother Bank in Windham County.---0f Trustees. of Hartford Female Seminary for an act of ncorporation.---Of Samuel Colt and oth- CTS for a lottery.--Of North Society of Killingly to be made a town.--Of Daniel l.. Colt and others for division of the town of fNorwicb.-Of Nathan Champlia and others, of West Chelsea in Norwich, ts be incorporated into . new town by the name of Mount Pleasant. Of-----:for a Bank in T Tolland.- Of Peabody and others for Lottery. The above petitions. with several others principally Of a private ma tnre. were disposed of hy reference to committes. VIZ, Nj

 The joint committee ds the subject 0f the State House in Hartfdsd, reported that they had examined the outer walls and in teriior of the building, and found tho same cosiderabiy out of repairs and recommend that the necessary repairs should he made. -&.
